title: Boy accused of killing his family sobs in court after judge explains big words
text:
Kyle Alwood, 9, sobbed in court as he faced charges of murdering five close relatives including including half-sister Rose, top right, and half-brother Daemeon, bottom right (Pictures: CBS News/Legacy.com)

A nine year-old boy accused of murdering five close relatives in a house fire sobbed after his lawyer explained big words to him in court.

Kyle Alwood was so small he could hardly be seen from behind in the chair during the hearing in Eureka, Illinois on Monday, with his feet barely touching the ground.

He said he struggled to comprehend what was happening, prompting Judge Charles Feeney to ask: ‘What don’t you understand?’, according to the Chicago Tribune.

Kyle replied: ‘What I did.’

Feeney then paused repeatedly to explain various terms in charging documents, with his lawyer again halting the hearing to say Kyle did not understand what ‘alleged’ means.

Kyle reportedly killed (L-R) Rose Alwood, Dameon Wall and Dameon’s sister Ariel Wall (Pictures: Legacy.com)

The judge answered: ‘It means someone accuses you. Kyle’s lawyer then interrupted again saying the youngster wanted to know what the word ‘arson’ meant, prompting Feeney to tell him: ‘You knowingly set a fire.’ The youngster – accused of killing his two toddler half-siblings, toddler cousin, mother’s boyfriend and step-great-grandma-to-be in April, broke down as the hearing came to a close.

He left the court sobbing with his arms folded as the gravity of his situation appeared to dawn on him. The youngster was accompanied by his paternal grandfather, News9 reported.

Kyle is accused of deliberately setting his family’s trailer home in Goodfield, Illinois, ablaze and murdering his two year-old half-brother Daemeon Wall and one year-old half-sister Ariel Wall.

Also killed in the blaze was Daemeon and Ariel’s great-grandma Kathryn Murray, 69, and her grandson Jason Wall (Pictures: Legacy.com)

His two year-old cousin Rose Alwood also died in the blaze, as did his stepdad Jason Wall, 34, and Wall’s grandma Kathryn Murray, 69.

All five died of smoke inhalation, with eyewitnesses hearing their screams as the trailer burned.

Kyle’s fate will be decided by a judge, rather than a jury trial.

If convicted, the youngster will not be sent to prison, and is likely to face around five years probation, with any such punishment concluded by the time he turns 21.

Earlier this month, his mother Katie Alwood spoke out to identify her son, insist that Kyle is not a monster, and say that she forgives him for what he allegedly did.

All five were killed in this April 2019 blaze at a mobile home in Goodfield, Illinois (Picture: Shawn Johnson)

Katie told CBS News: ‘Everyone is looking at him like he’s some kind of monster, but that’s not who he is.

‘People make mistakes, and that’s what this is.

‘Yes, it was a horrible tragedy, but it’s still not something to throw his life away over.’

Katie has since been hit with a gagging order preventing her from speaking about her son again. She is currently in hospital being treated for an unspecified illness.

Explaining his reasoning for charging Kyle, prosecutor Greg Minger said the decision was a ‘heavy’ one.

He added: ‘It’s a tragedy, but at the end of the day it’s charging a very young person with one of the most serious crimes we have.

‘But I just think it needs to be done at this point, for finality.’

Kyle is due back in court for a pre-trial hearing on November 22.
